He has been working for twenty years and so has a lot of experience.  However, he knows that the work is hard and he hires day laborers when it is the season to harvest and weed his fields.  He takes the fruit that he harvests to middlemen who pay him very well for every kilogram of produce that he sells.  The problem in his work lies in not being able to fight the pests which damage the fruit on his plants.  However, his main priority right now is buying new land as he doesn't have enough space to continue sowing.

This is Epifanio's fifth loan from MFP and he pledges to continue making his repayments on time as he did with his previous loans.  He is grateful to the other members of his community bank for electing him as president of the board of directors.  He will use the loan he has requested to buy cacao plants which he will then sow using modern technology.

loans.use: to buy cacao plants

loans.name: Memunatu

texts.en: Memunatu sells food items such as salted fish, oil, soaps, rice, steel-wool and other items at Abura. Demand for her goods has started increasing and so she needs a loan of 1000 to buy more food items for resale. She is married and has three children. Her husband sells provisions. Memunatu has been trading for 4 years. She helps her husband in the general upkeep of the home. She hopes to use the new profits from her business to educate her children.

loans.use: to buy more food items for resale.

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled is a 40 year-old married man, who lives with his wife and four children in Ain. He has worked in car repair since 1988 and is very experienced in this field. Most of his customers recommend him to others. Khaled has been an A. Majmoua-Kiva partner for ten consecutive cycles and all his previous loans helped improve his business and his family’s sociA. and financiA. situation a lot. Khaled seeks perfection in his business, which is why he’s requesting a loan to buy new, improved machines that will help improve his business more and more. He hopes to stay updating and improving his business through offering a wider set of services in the future.

loans.use: to buy new machines that will help improve his business

loans.name: Marceline

texts.fr:
Marié, 51ans d’âge, maman de 4 enfants dont l’âge varie entre 13ans et 27ans, et ayant une personne à charge qui avec son CEP est devenue vendeuse de foufou en 1997 avec  un capital de 150.000 frs CFA.

Le marche qui est son le lieu d’activité est parmi le plus grand et le plus fréquenter de la capital.ses ventes varies entre 10000f et 20000f par jour.

Avec le second prêt actuel, elle veut acheter  6 sacs de foufou.

Comme une bonne maman, elle a un souci particulier pour ses enfants celui de les aider dans leurs entreprises pour ceux qui sont déjà indépendant et soutenir les plus jeune dans leurs cursus scolaire.
texts.en:
This woman is 51 years old, married, and has four children who are between the ages 13 and 27, and also has one additional person in her care. With her CEP (local community fund), she became a retailer of fufu (a staple food eaten in West and Central Africa) in 1997 with 150,000 FCFA worth of capital.

The market where she runs her business is among the largest and most-visited in the capital. Her sales vary from 10,000F to 20,000F per day.

With the current (her second) loan, she would like to buy 6 bags of fufu.

As a good mother, she takes special care of her children, including helping those who are already independent with their businesses, and providing for the education of the younger ones.

loans.use: To buy bags of fufu (a staple West and Central African food)

loans.name: Felix Antonio

texts.es: Félix hombre trabajador casado, su esposa comerciante, sus hijos ya independiente le ayudan a sus padres. Proyecto mejorar la infraestructura de su vivienda. Tiene su propio negocio ya que es de profesión albañil desde hace tiempo trabajando por temporada proyectos, pero también trabaja por cuenta propia.  El préstamo lo requiere para la compra de materiales de construcción como: cemento, arena, piedrines, bloques, piedras cantera, hierro, tablones de maderas, entre otros materiales para construir un muro de la propiedad. Obtenida protección, seguridad para sus seres queridos.
texts.en: Félix is a hard working married man.  His wife is a merchant and his children, already on their own, help their parents.  He wants to improve the infrastructure of his home.  He has his own business and works as a mason, both on formal projects and on his own.  He will use the money from this loan to buy building materials such as cement, sand, stone, cinder blocks, quarry stone, iron bars, plywood sheets, among other things that he will use to build a wall around his property.  This will provide security for his loved ones.

loans.use: to buy building materials

loans.name: Jeanine

texts.en:
Jeanine is a 27-year-old Rwandan entrepreneur with two children ages three and five. Both of her children are in school and her husband is a farmer. For the past three years, Jeanine has been selling second-hand clothes. Her business profit has helped her meet the needs of her family.

Jeanine is requesting a loan to purchase goods such as baby clothes, baby sheets, bedcovers, and shirts to sell. With the future profits from her business, she wishes to buy a piece of land.

loans.use: to buy baby clothes, sheets, and bedcovers to sell

loans.name: Susi

texts.en:
Susi is 48 years old and married, with 2 children.  She earns a living buying and selling livestock in the Philippines. 

Susi is borrowing PHP 24,000 through NWTF to buy additional livestock to raise and sell.  Susi has been buying and selling livestock for 20 years and also earns additional income from a networking business (Avon products) and farming rice.

She is working tirelessly toward the attainment of her dream: to save enough to provide a secure future for her family.

loans.use: To buy additional livestock to raise and sell

loans.name: Mayang Sari Group

texts.en:
Sariasih is a mother of four children. Now she is 41 years old. In 1999, she opened a kiosk to sell rice and side dishes like tofu, tempeh, fish, and vegetables. This business has been running well until now. 

Because now is a fasting month, she will use part of her loan to pay for bananas, sugar, yams and coconut milk. These are the ingredients to make "kolak". Kolak is like an appetizer for the "iftar" (breaking the fast). It is sweet and the main ingredient is bananas. In the future, she wants to save her money and repair her house.

loans.use: to pay for bananas, sugar, yams, and coconut milk.

loans.name: Nancy

texts.es: Nancy de 44 años, vive con su esposo y sus 3 hijos en las edades de 9 a 18 años en el municipio de Soledad, área metropolitana de Barranquilla. Allí tiene una tienda miscelánea, donde vende artículos de la canasta familiar y mercancías como cosméticos, accesorios femeninos, ropa, calzado, papelería y plásticos. Negocio que inició hace 14 años, cuando fue liquidada por una importante almacén de cadenas, donde trabajó y este dinero lo aplicó a su aventura emprendedora. Ella inició con 2 vitrinas en la terraza de una casa arrendada, ubicada  frente su residencia actual, la que  en menos de 1 año logró comprar. Con el apoyo de la Fundación Mario Santo Domingo amplió su negocio, consiguió pagar estudios universitarios de su hijo y quiere continuar siendo exitosa con el aumento de su capital de trabajo. Esta es la razón por la cual acude y aprovecha su credikiva pues quiere invertir en papelería, accesorios y fantasías,  con los que recibirá el mes en el cual se requiere mas inversión en los negocios,  por que así mismo las ventas repuntan, debido a que se celebra el día del amor y de la amistad y las  compras de niños y adultos crecen, pues todos quieren mostrar su cariño con obsequios para sus amigos, novios, familiares vecinos y efectivamente,  los clientes de Nancy planean ir a su miscelánea a comprar un buen regalo y ella debe tener surtido su negocio con todo lo que ellos exijan. El negocio de Nancy maneja un margen de contribución del 20% una rotación de inventarios de 90 días y una rentabilidad de 12% desde la cual auguramos su exitosa inversión y su potencial crecimiento.
texts.en:
Nancy, age 44, lives with her husband and their three children.  The children range in age from 9 to 18.  They live in the Soledad municipality, a metropolitan area in Barranquilla.  

That is where she has a store where she sells everyday food products and merchandise like cosmetics, women’s accessories, clothes, shoes, stationery items, and plastic products.  She started the business 14 years ago when she was let go from the important chain of stores where she worked.  She used this money for her entrepreneurial adventure.

She started with two display cases on the terrace of a rented house, which is located in front of her house.  In less than one year she managed to buy it.  With the support of the Fundación Mario Santo Domingo she expanded her business and paid for her son’s university education.  

She wants to continue being successful with an increase in her working capital.  That is the reason she turns to Kiva and makes use of her Kiva loan.  She wants to buy stationery products, accessories, and novelty items.  She will receive them in the month that requires more investment in the businesses.  This is when sales increase due to the celebration of Valentine’s Day (day of love and friendship).  Children’s and adults’ purchases increase.  Everyone wants to show their affection with gifts for their friends, boyfriends and girlfriends, family members, and neighbors.  Indeed, Nancy’s customers plan to go to her store to buy a nice present.  She needs to have her business stocked with everything they require.

Nancy maintains a contribution margin of 12%, from which we predict her successful investment and potential growth.

loans.use: to buy stationery products, accessories, and novelty items

loans.name: Sevilla

texts.en:
Sevilla is 54 years old and lives in Sapang Dalaga. She is married with four children. 

To earn a living, Sevilla has a business selling snacks. She earns about PHP 3600 each month doing this type of work. Sevilla has requested a loan of 14,950 to purchase 2 sacks of flour and other ingredients.

Sevilla has been a member of PMPC for five years.

loans.use: To purchase two sacks of flour and other ingredients.

location.town: Calamba-Sapang Ama Sapang Dalaga Misamis Occidenta

loans.name: Betty

texts.en:
Betty is 29 years old married woman, with one child who is in school.

She has a business selling beans, rice and tomatoes in bulk in South Sudan.  Betty has been in business for four years.

Betty requested this loan through BRAC with the hopes of expanding her business.  She says the extra income will be used to open a nursery school.

loans.use: to expand her business.

loans.name: Avliyokul

texts.ru: Авлиёкул проживает в районе Дангара. Возраст, 35 лет. Женат. Имеет троих детей. Двое его детей учатся в школе, а другой маленький. Сам Авлиёкул занимается торговлей на рынке. Он занимается продажей занавесей и тканей. Этим видом деятельности занимается 13 лет. Кредит берет для увеличения товарооборота. Он хочет купить несколько рулонов однотонные тканей.
texts.en: Avliyokul lives in the Dangara district.  He is 35 years old, married and has three children.  Two of his children attend a school, and the other one is still very small.  Avliyokul is involved in sales at the market.  He sells drapes and fabrics.  He has been in this business for 13 years.  Avliyokul is requesting this loan to increase goods turnover.  He wants to buy several rolls of solid-color fabrics.

loans.use: to purchase solid-color fabrics

loans.name: Rosa Argentina

texts.es:
Doña Rosa, sigui con su labor de promotora social en la comunidad que vive, pues este trabajo le permite sastifaccion personal, al poder ayudar a muchos niños en condiciones muy pobre.
Atrave de estos financiamiento, ha logrado la mejora habitacional, que junto con su familia, se apoyan entre si, su esposo sigue con su trabajo de fotografia, asi mismo cuenta con el aporte economico de su hija, quien labora como medico. Con su credito anterior logro el cambo de techo, y levantar paredes de muro. Hoy con este nuevo financiamiento comenzara la construccion de un cuarto en la parte de atrás del patio, teniendo mayor espacio y privacidad, ya que sus tres hijos viven en la casa.
texts.en:
Rosa still works as a social promoter in the community where she lives because this job gives her personal satisfaction and she’s able to help many children living in poverty.

Through these loans she’s managed to do some home improvements.  Her family supports each other; her husband continues working as a photographer and her daughter, who works as a physician, also helps out economically.

She used the previous loan to replace the roof and build concrete walls.  Now, with this new loan she will start adding a room to the rear of the patio for more space and privacy since her three children still live at home.

loans.use: to add a room to the rear of her house.

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: to purchase stock and make alterations to her store.

loans.name: Yanjmaa

texts.en:
Mrs. Yanjmaa, 56, runs a grocery store in the ger district. A ger is a traditional nomadic Mongolian tent. She lives with her niece in a ger. Her store opened in the autumn of 2010. Her business has been running successfully and already has some permanent customers. 

Now she needs to make some renovation to her store in order to improve her business in the future. She needs new bulks, commodities and a freezer to keep these commodities.

The loan she is taking will be used to cover the cost of new furniture and a freezer for her grocery store.

loans.use: to cover the cost of new furniture and a freezer for her grocery store.

loans.name: Reina Johanna

texts.es:
Reina de 32 años, empezó con su bazar hace 1 año atrás por que trabaja en su casa y así puede pasar tiempo con sus hijos. Trabaja todos los días de 8 de la mañana hasta las 8 de la noche.

El problema que presenta es la delincuencia debido al que el sector es muy peligroso.

Madres soltera con 3 hijos; los dos últimos hijos de 11 años y 4 años estudia en escuela fiscal. Con el prestamo quiere comprar ropa, laminas y bebidas para su negocio. 

Su meta alcanzar es poder agrandar mas el negocio y poder terminar de construir su casa para una mejor comodidad.
texts.en:
Reina, age 32, opened her variety store one year ago so that she could work from home and spend time with her children. She works every day from 8:00 am to 8:00 pm.
Crime is an issue for her because she lives in a very dangerous area.
She is a single mother with three children. The two older children, ages 11 and 4, attend public school. With this loan, Reina will purchase clothing, educational materials and drinks for her business.
Her goal is to be able to expand her business more and to be able to finish building her home in order to have better living conditions.

loans.use: to buy more clothing, educational materials, and pop.

loans.name: Margarita

texts.es:
Margarita, de 27 años, está casada con Rudy. Ambos tienen 2 hijos: Jack, de 9 y Anahi, de 3 años. Margarita y su familia viven en la casa de su madre, ubicada en la localidad de Puente Paucartambo. Margarita tiene múltiples oficios y habilidades. En su localidad caracterizada por la producción de frutas y café, se encarga de elaborar cajones como contenedores de frutos como: plátanos y paltas. En todo este tiempo pudo juntar un capital de dinero necesario para poder abrir un restaurante de anticuchos, hamburguesas y salchipapas. Los que en todo este tiempo, tiene gran acogida. “Las personas ya me conocen por eso siempre vienen a comer, además en estas comidas no hay pierde”, comenta. 
A su vez, cuenta con terrenos agrícolas en los que siembra café, plátanos y paltas, los que comercializa con éxito en el mercado mayorista de La Merced.  Ahora ella quiere comprar más terrenos agrícolas y espera dentro de muy poco concretar un acuerdo de venta, pero sin descuidarse de su negocio. Su principal preocupación es su cultivo de café, ya que cuanto más invierta, mayor será su ganancia. Este sería su préstamo número 10 que obtendría gracias a su ayuda, de MFP. Por esa razón se compromete a ser puntual en el pago de sus cuotas. A la vez menciona sentirse contenta trabajando dentro de su banco comunal, por la solidaridad que encuentra en él.
De obtener el dinero del crédito, Margarita podrá abrir una tienda de productos de primera necesidad, para ello comprará algunos muebles y mercadería.
texts.en:
Margarita, 27, is married to Rudy and has 2 children: Jack, 9, and Anahi, 3. Margarita and her family live with her mother in the village of Puente Paucartambo. Margarita has many trades and abilities. Her town is known for producing fruit and coffee, so Margarita makes packing crates for fruits like plantains and avocados. Over time, she has put together enough capital to open a restaurant that sells anticuchos [cow heart kebabs], hamburgers and salchipapas [sausages with french fries]. The business has been very well received. "People already know me and so they always come to eat, and also with these foods there isn't profit loss," she says.

In addition, she also has farmland where she plants coffee, plantains and avocados which she sells successfully in the wholesale market in La Merced. Now she wants to buy more land and hopes very soon to close a sale, but without neglecting her business. Her main concern is her coffee crop, because the more the invests the more she'll earn. 

This will be her 10th loan with MFP and she promises to make her payments punctually. She is happy that she is working with the village bank because of the solidarity that she finds there. Upon receipt of the loan, Margarita will buy some furniture and merchandise so she can open a store with basic goods.

loans.use: to buy shelves, counters and products to stock her store.

loans.name: Christine

texts.en:
Christine is a 35-year-old married woman with five children, all of whom are in school. She has had a business of selling charcoal in Yambio, South Sudan, for three years.

Christine is requesting this loan through BRAC South Sudan to purchase charcoal. She will use her extra income from this loan to build a concrete house in the future.

loans.use: to purchase charcoal for sale.

loans.name: Las Comadres Group

texts.es:
Este grupo se llama las Comadres sus integrantes decidieron ponerle  así por que la mayoría de las integrantes son comadres y todas se caen bien y son coma familia todas comadres de todas.
Este grupo esta conformado por  once señoras   trabajadoras  y un señor trabajador y honesto el compadre de todas.
La representante del grupo es la señora Librada Minerva mas  bien conocida como doña Mine la de los licuados.
Sus compañeras de grupo le dicen así por que haces licuados  de productos  de Herbalife  para la salud.
Doña Mine se caracteriza por ser una señora trabajadora ,le gusta mucho salir adelante romper todas las barreras y cumplir sus sueños ,tener a su familia unida y ayudar a sus compañeras de grupo para que todo este bien .
Doña Mine cuenta con un local donde vende productos de Herbalife como son tes, licuados  y agua , ella nos cuenta que le gusta mucho su trabajo por que obtiene buenas ganancias y tanbien ayuda  a las personas ofreciendo cosas naturales .
Doña Mine esta felizmente casada con el señor Javier quien esta en los estados unidos , pero gracias adiós  y a fundación 
por que con la su ayuda de fundación doña Mine tiene su local y mas producto para que su esposo regrese y los dos trabajan juntos.
Ella  pidió  el préstamo para comprar mas productos de herbalife  para poder vender mas y obtener mas ganancias.
Las otras integrantes del grupo son:
Rosa Elia- quien se dedica a la venta de zapatos.
Tomasa- se dedica a la venta de dulces.
Margarito   German- se dedica a la venta de zapatos.
Lorena-  se dedica a la venta de perfumes.
Guadalupe se dedica a la venta de pollos.
Isabel se dedica a la venta de perfumes.
Rosa – se dedica a la venta de pescados.
Teresa- se dedica a la venta de  pollos.
Romulda- se dedica a la venta de antojitos mexicanos.
Margarita – se dedica a la venta de pollos.
Verónica – se dedica a la venta de pollos.

Le dan las gracias a fundación por ayudarlas  a cumplir sus sueños y  a tener un negocio para ayudar a sus familias.
texts.en:
This group is called “Las Comadres.”  The members decided on this name because most of them are comadres [have baptized each other’s children]; they like each other and are like family all of them together.  The group has 11 hardworking women and one hardworking, honest man who is compadre to all of them.  The group representative is Librada Minerva, better known as Doña Mine, the blended drinks lady.  Her fellow members call her that because she makes Herbalife blended drinks for health.

Doña Mine is noted for being a hardworking woman who likes to go out and tear down all barriers and reach her dreams; to have a united family and to help her fellow group members so that everything is OK.

Doña Mine has a locale where she sells Herbalife products like teas, blended drinks and water.  She tells us that she enjoys her work very much because she earns good profits and also helps people by selling them natural products.

Doña Mine is happily married to Javier who is in the United States but thanks to God and to the Fundación Mine has her locale and more products so that her husband can return and they can work together. She requested the loan to buy more Herbalife products to sell and earn higher profits.

The other group members are:

Rosa Elia- sells shoes.
Tomasa- sells candy.
Margarito German- sells shoes.
Lorena- sells perfume.
Guadalupe – sells chickens.
Isabel – sells perfume.
Rosa – sells fish.
Teresa- sells chicken.
Romulda- sells traditional Mexican fast food snacks.
Margarita – sells chickens.
Verónica – sells chickens.

They thank the Fundación for helping them reach their dreams and to have a business to help their families.

loans.use: to buy Herbalife products to sell.

loans.name: Sokhorn's Group

texts.en:
Forty-year-old Sokhorn is the breadwinner of her female-headed family in a village in the Tbaung Khmum district. She is a mother of five dependent children who are still in school. To survive this family, she has been working in a cornfield and growing vegetables for several years. However, she can manage to save only $1 US dollar from her daily income of $4 U.S. dollars.

This is Sokhorn's first group loan with VisionFund and she is a leader of a two-member group. She will use this loan to buy fertilizer and pay for labor for her farmland. She hopes to improve her family's living conditions and to keep her children in school.

loans.use: To buy fertilizer and pay for laborers

location.town: Kampong Cham province, Tbaung Khmum district

loans.name: Chamroeurn

texts.en: Chamroeurn, 34 years-old, is married and resides with his wife and two children in Battambang Province, Cambodia. He has been a sculptor for over ten years and is successful in his career. His wife is a homemaker. He wants to build a new house. Due to a lack of funds, Chamroeurn is requesting a loan of USD 1,000 in order to purchase construction materials to build his house. In the future, he would like to expand his business and support his children to study until they get Bachelor degrees.

loans.use: to purchase construction materials to build his house.

loans.name: Maria Milagro

texts.es:
María, desea continuar trabajando con créditos para fortalecer su negocio, en esta oportunidad comprara sal, arroz, maíz, aceite, detergente, etc., así podrá atender las demandas de sus clientes.
Con los créditos ella ha mejorado mucho su negocio de tienda y pupusería, ofrece un inventario más surtido, sus ganancias son mejores y ha cancelado sus deudas.

loans.use: comprara sal, arroz, maíz, aceite, detergente, etc., así podrá atender las demandas de sus clientes

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: To increase on their capital

loans.name: Nazime

texts.en: Nazima is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied Fizuli district of Azerbaijan. She fled to Baku in 1993 and started her own business in 1996. During 2005-2006 she borrowed two times from the Normicro Baku branch a total of $2,400. Nazima wants to borrow an additional $1,200 to expand the variety of trade goods in her shop.

loans.use: To increase the variety of trade goods inventory.

loans.name: Araceli

texts.en:
Araceli is married and mother of three children, 20, 23 and 24 years old. The older boys are married, only the younger daughter lives with her. Aracelli’s husband is a driver, but she realized that she needed to help with the expenses. Four years ago she started her retail business of clothes, shoes, décor and jewellery.

Demand has been growing and to meet it, Araceli needs a loan of $750. She will buy merchandise to offer more variety to her customers. You can support this business and improve this family’s standard of living. They thank you for your help.

Translated from Spanish by Virgilio Russi, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Araceli es casada, madre de tres hijos, de 20, 23 y 24 años de edad, los dos hijos mayores ya están casados y sólo la hija menor vive con ella, su esposo labora como chofer, pero Araceli veía la necesidad de tener un ingreso extra para ayudar en los gastos del hogar, esto es lo que la motivó a iniciar su negocio hace cuatro años, vendiendo productos al menudeo, como ropa, tenis, artículos de decoración y joyería.

La demanda por sus productos se ha incrementado y para cubrir las necesidades de sus clientes, Araceli requiere de un préstamo por la cantidad de $ 750 dólares que empleará en la compra de mercancía, para poder ofrecer más variedad a sus clientes y brindar un buen servicio. Tú puedes contribuir al crecimiento de este negocio y a mejorar la vida de esta familia, ellos agradecen sinceramente tu ayuda.

loans.use: purchase merchandise

loans.name: Marie

texts.en: Marie Mardy is a 38-year-old from Haiti who now resides in a small community near the northern coast of the Dominican Republic. She has run her "Colmado Rosa" out of her home for more than two years. Marie has been approved for this loan of $150 to purchase sugar, milk and rice so she can restock her inventory. She has applied for this new loan so she can continue expanding her business, which is the source of income to support her children, Oscor (4), Martin (7), Estephani (8) and Piter (8).

loans.use: Purchase sugar, milk & rice

loans.name: Silvestre

texts.es:
I run a hair salon at my home. I would like to buy new furniture, like chairs, mirrors and armchairs, to better serve my clients and make them more comfortable, and to increase my clientele. I am requesting $1000 to acquire new furniture for my business.

Translated from Spanish by Leticia Britos, Kiva Volunteer.

Tengo un negocio de peluquería en mi vivienda y me gustarla comprar mobiliario nuevo, como sillas, espejos y sillones para atender mejor a mis clientes, que estén más cómodos y así aumentar mi clientela. Solicito $1000 para comprar mobiliario nuevo para mi negocio.

loans.use: Improve my business

loans.name: Laudovina

texts.en:
Laudovina is 54 years old and has 9 children and 11 grandchildren – 7 of whom still live with her in her house. Her husband is a truck driver transporting produce through the nearby cities.

Laudovina's business is selling gasoline from her home, which is near the large road connecting the two major cities of El Seybo and La Romana. The nearest gas station is in a large town about 40 minutes away, so the people in her community appreciate being able to go directly to her. The majority of her clients are passing “motoconchos” (motorcycle taxis) and agricultural delivery trucks.

Laudovina took out her first loan with Esperanza 2 years ago for 3000 pesos (US$ 90). This is the 4th loan that she is going to take out from Esperanza, and she has successfully paid back the other 3. Esperanza typically offers smaller loans initially and as a group of women successfully pay back their loans and get a credit history, they can borrow increasingly larger amounts. Laudovina is pictured at her biweekly repayment meeting.

With her first loan from Esperanza, Laudovina started her business from the ground up, and she has been able to progressively build up her small business to serve more and more people. With the profits she makes from her small gas station, she is able to buy food for her family and help provide for her children and grandchildren.

loans.use: To invest in her business

loans.name: Kodjo

texts.fr:
Born in Agomé-Glozou in 1962, Mr. Kodjo A. is married and provides for a total of 10 people. His wife has a little store whose income also goes toward family expenses. Mr. Kodjo A. became a farmer by choice and is now referred to as "friend of the earth". His great experience makes him an excellent farmer. Currently, in order to cope with increased demand for his crops, he would like to improve the productivity of his fields. For this reason, he is requesting a loan of US$ 400 to purchase fertilizer. The income from the sale of his harvest will permit him to save a bit, to improve living conditions for his family, and especially to provide for his children's education.

Translated from French by Teresa Kramer, Kiva volunteer

Né à Agomé-glozou en 1962, Monsieur Kodjo A. est marié et a à sa charge un total de dix (10) personnes. Sa femme, petite revendeuse contribue aux charges du ménage. Devenu paysan à son gré, monsieur Kodjo A. est surnommé aujourd’hui « ami de la terre ». Ses nombreuses expériences lui confèrent le statut d’un grand paysan. Aujourd’hui, pour faire face à la demande élevée, il a besoin d’augmenter la productivité de ses champs. A cet effet, il sollicite ce crédit de $400 pour acheter des fertilisants afin d’enrichir ses champs. Les recettes tirées de la vente des récoltes lui permettront d’épargner son compte, et d’améliorer les conditions de vie de sa famille en général et d’étude de ses enfants en particulier.

loans.use:
Purchase of fertilizer

Achat des fertilisants

loans.name: Mumtaz

texts.en: I am Mumtaz S.. I am married and a mother of four: two sons and two daughters. Currently, only my eldest girl attends school, while the others are small and do not attend school. I embroider clothes and my husband is a tailor. Now my husband needs to buy  two sewing machines, one for himself and one for the worker that he has hired for his shop. Please lend us $175 for this purpose.

loans.use: Buy sewing machines for the business

loans.name: Thi Hue

texts.vi:
Mrs Huê is 22. She has a young child. Her main occupation is selling grocery from home. She makes 3-5 USD a day. She has contracted a loan from lender before but she has repaid since then. Now she applies to SEDA for a loan of 150 USD because it is much simpler and the loan term is favorable. She will use the money to stock up her inventory thus raising her income.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Huê, 22 tuổi, có 1 con nhỏ. Chị làm nghề bán hàng tạp hoá tại gia đình. Thu nhập bình quân từ 50000 - 80000đ/ngày. Trước, chị có vay ở ngoài, nhưng giờ đã trả hết. Nay, chị vay 2006000đ theo Chương trình Tài chính vi mô binhminh cdc vì thủ tục vay ở đây khá đơn giản, lại được trả góp hàng tuần. Số tiền chị vay được, chị dùng để lấy thêm hàng bán, tăng thu nhập cho gia đình

loans.use: stock up inventory for her grocery store

loans.name: Anna

texts.en:
This is 26 year-old Anna S.. She is married with four children, aged 4, 7, 10, and 14.

Anna owns a textile and catering business, and requires a loan in order to purchase additional stocks of material in bulk, as well as ingredients and utensils for her catering business. Anna thanks you for your support.

loans.use: To purchase ingredients and utensils for her catering business, and additional stocks of material for her textile business.

loans.name: Muhamed

texts.en:
Muhamed C. is 70 years old, but is still strong enough to do farm work. Muhamed has 10 children, of which, 4 are now married.

With a loan from Salone Microfinance Trust (SMT), he was able to harvest 40 bags of rice. He sold 15 bags and used the cash to buy other crops, like pepper to resell to earn more income. He is happy that his children have enough food this year. He would like to grow more crops for both consumption and for sale. He plans to build a better house for the family. Muhamed is therefore requesting a loan of Le.1, 000,000.

Muhamed has lived his life as a farmer. With his recent help from SMT, and hopefully, from Kiva, he will continue his new life as a successful farmer who can easily feed his family and care for them they way he always wanted.

loans.use: To grow more crops for consumption and sale

loans.name: Bui Thi

texts.vi:
Mrs Bùi Thị M., 58 years old, joined TYM as a member in 2002. She lives in Kim Động, Hưng Yên with her husband and their 3 children. Her main occupation is tending her rice field and raising poultry. Before joining TYM, she had only a dozen of chickens. Her monthly income was 30 USD. Today, there are about 200 heads in her chicken coop. These are egg laying chickens as well as for their meat. Her income has increased to 130 USD a month. Her husband is a peasant farmer. He always helps her out when she needs a hand. This time she is requesting a loan of 950 USD to buy feed for her chickens.

Translated from Vietnamese by Khang Ho-Si, Kiva volunteer.

Chị Bùi Thị M., 58 tuổi, tham gia Quỹ Tình thương năm 2002. Chị sống cùng chồng và 3 con tại Kim Động, Hưng Yên. Công việc chủ yếu của chị là làm ruộng và chăn nuôi gà. Lúc trước chị M. chỉ có khoảng trên dưới chục con gà, thu nhập từ chăn nuôi chỉ có 30USD/tháng. Sau khi vào Quỹ, lượng vốn đầu tư tăng lên, hiện trong chuồng nhà chị có hơn 200 con gà thịt và gà đẻ. Thu nhập hàng tháng cũng tăng lên 130USD. Chồng chị M., một người nông dân hiền lành, chất phác, luôn giúp đỡ chị trong công việc đồng áng và chăn nuôi. Vòng vốn này chị xin vay 950USD để mua thức ăn cho đàn gà của mình.

loans.use: Buy feed for her chickens

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia B., wife of M.S., lives in a 2 room brick house. She has three daughters and one son. One daughter is in 8th standard, the second daughter is in 5th standard. Her son is in 2nd standard. Her husband has run a grocery shop for the last 6 years. His daily income is $6 to $7. She has applied for a loan for her husband’s grocery shop business.

She has been joined in her loan group by a few other members: Shamim B. wants a loan to start a wood business; Razia B. wants a loan to start a fruit business; Rani B. wants a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw; Rubina B. wants a loan to start a grocery business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members mutually guarantee one another's loans. If one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: Give expansion to their businesses

loans.name: Villa Ascencion Group

texts.en:
Maria J. B. understands what it is like to struggle to survive. Each day of her life has been hand to mouth as she tries to provide for her 10 children. An immigrant from Haiti, Maria and her husband, Wilson, live in Puerto Plata, Dominican Republic. Maria sells sweets made out of cocoa, peanuts, and sugar to provide for the seven children that are currently living in her house. (The others are still in Haiti). She dreams of owning her own home one day but is primarily concerned with supporting her children for the time being.

Maria J. B. is just one member of the 10-person micro-bank, Villa Ascencion, which means “Ascended Town”. Each of these unique Dominican entrepreneurs unite in solidarity, allowing them to access funding that they would otherwise never be able to receive on their own. The concept of this group bank paying their loan together is to reduce the risk of one person defaulting, as the other members gladly help cover one another’s payments in order to receive their next loan together. Some of the other women in this particular bank make a living selling clothing or running small salons, and one owns a small colmado, or store that sells basic groceries and snacks.

On behalf of Maria, the Villa Ascension, and the entire team here at Esperanza International, we thank you for your support and awareness of the global issue of poverty, in which your efforts are helping to make a difference.

loans.use: To purchase sugar, peanuts, and cocoa, as well as clothing, shoes, and inventory for a small store.

loans.name: Marlene Esperanza

texts.es:
Señora Marlene is married and is 47 years old. She studied to be a secretary and she has 2 children who still depend on her. She lives in the neighborhood of Víctor Larco Provincia de Trujillo, La Libertad. Currently, she works making chocolate candies and at the same time making costume jewelry. She sells her chocolates in the shops closest to her house which have very good acceptance in the winter. In the summer she spends more time making and selling costume jewelry. The first loan that she recieved was for S/.300.00, that she invested in the purchase of materials for the costume jewelry. She belongs to the Community Bank "Las Palmeras" which she joined by invitation from a friend. With thel oan of S/.800.00, that she will repay in 6 months, she thinks she will begin buying and selling shoes and by this method grow her business. She dreams of being a large microenterprise and to run a nice market.

Translated from Spanish by Jessica Kaminsky, Kiva Volunteer.

La señora Marlene está casada, tiene 47 años, estudió secretariado y tiene 02 hijos que aún dependen de ella; vive en el distrito de Víctor Larco Provincia de Trujillo, La Libertad. Actualmente, se dedica a la preparación de chocotejas y al mismo tiempo confecciona joyas de fantasía; Realiza la venta de chocotejas a las bodegas más cercanas de su casa las cuales tienen muy buena aceptación en la temporada de invierno, en la temporada de verano brinda mayor dedicación a la confección y venta de joyas de fantasía. El primer préstamo que recibió fue de S/.300.00, los que invirtió en la compra de materiales para la confección de bisutería. Pertenece al Banco Comunal “LAS PALMERAS” al cual ingresó por invitación de una amiga. Con el préstamo de S/.800.00, que cancelará en un plazo de 06 meses; tiene pensado dedicarse a la compra y venta de zapatos y de esa forma ampliar su negocio. Sueña con ser una gran microempresaria y contar con un bazar muy surtido.

loans.use: To buy better materials for chocolates and jewelry

loans.name: Comité Las Maravillas Group

texts.es:
This group called “Las Maravillas” (The Wonders), was formed in March of 2008. The Fundacion Paraguaya advisor spoke with Mrs. Ciriaca A. about how the Enterprising Women Group program works and Ciriaca began explaining it to her neighbors; she was able to round up 15 women who now form the Wonders Group.

The group members will use their loans for different activities such as: sale of tobacco, sale of clothing such as t-shirts, pants, dress shirts, and lingerie; others sell bookstore items, and one of the women has a small warehouse where she sells sugar, baked goods, oil, meat, etc.

All the women participate in the weekly meetings and work hard to collect funds to pay back the loan. The group works together very well, demonstrating a sense of companionship and solidarity.

Translated from Spanish by Scott Crandall, Kiva Volunteer.

El Grupo denominado Las Maravillas, se conformó en marzo de 2008, dicho grupo fue conformado por promociones hechas por la asesora, quien en esa ocasión habló con la señora Ciriaca A. acerca de como funciona el programa de Comité de Mujeres Emprendedoras. Dicha señora comenzó a comentarles a sus vecinas y logró juntar a 15 mujeres las cuales integran hoy día el Comité Las Maravillas.

Las integrantes de este grupo destinan su crédito a diferentes actividades tales como: venta de tabacos, venta de ropas como remeras, pantalones, camisas y lencerías, otras venden artículos de librería, y una de ellas posee una despensa donde vende artículos como azúcar, panificados, aceite, carnes, etc.

Las mismas participan activamente en las reuniones semanales y realizan actividades para recaudar fondos. El grupo trabaja en forma conjunta, demuestran compañerismo y solidaridad.

loans.use: Purchase of tobacco for making cigarettes, purchase of bookstore items, meat, oil, baked goods, sugar, etc., clothing, and lingerie

loans.name: Nguyen Thi

texts.en: Mrs. Nguyen Thi M. is 48 years old. She joined TYM Fund in 1998. For the first cycle, she borrowed VND 500,000 to raise pigs. At present, she earns a living mainly by raising animals and farming. Her income is VND 4 million/month. For the next loan cycle, she wants to borrow VND 10 million to buy a buffalo to plough her rice fields.

loans.use: to buy a buffalo to plow her ricefields

loans.name: Assim

texts.en:
Assim is a 44-year-old man who lives with his wife and 3 children in a small village in Lebanon's Bekaa Valley. Assim works as a calligrapher. Calligraphy in Arabic is a highly specialized craft, as the characters require a great degree of skill to design and perfect. Assim designs posters and signs for locA. businesses and individuals, and delivers his pieces himself.

He has recently requested a loan of 1000 US Dollars from A. Majmoua which will be used to purchase new materials for his shop, such as paints and stencils, as well as to perform maintenance on the van which he uses to deliver his work. This will be Assim's first loan with A. Majmoua.

loans.use: To purchase new materials for Assim's calligraphy business, as well as to perform repairs on the van he uses to deliver his products.

loans.name: Rosa

texts.es: La señora Rosa Blass tiene la edad de 35 años habita en San Juan de la concepción comunidad los Martínez, junto a su esposo y sus hijos, el esposo es agricultor y comerciante de frutas, al igual que doña rosa, los sueños de ella es logra ampliar tanto la producción como su negocio, esta señora ha tenido siempre el apoyo de Afodenic y esta contenta ya que poco a poco esta logrando lo que se propuso hasta ahora , ella quiere darle mejor condición de vida a sus hijos ya que ellos están por salir de la secundaria y quiere que vayan a la universidad para verlos profesionales ya que ella no pudo estudiar quiere que sus hijos vivan mas cómodo.
texts.en:
Ms. Rosa B. is 35 years old and lives in the Martínez community of San Juan de la Concepción, along with her husband and children. Her husband is a farmer and a fruit vendor like Ms. Rosa. She dreams of expanding both her business and production. She has always had Afodenic’s support, and she is pleased because everything that she has set out to do has been achieved little by little. She wants to give her children better living conditions as they are almost finished with their secondary studies. She wants them to go on to college so that they can become professionals because she was unable to continue with her studies. She wants her children to live more comfortably.

Translated from Spanish by Elizabeth Casian, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase pesticides and fertilizer for crops

loans.name: Mohamed

texts.en:
Mohamed is a 35-year-old man who lives in Saida, a town in southern Lebanon, with his wife and their four children. Mohamed has been selling fruits and vegetables since 1989. He is requesting a loan of $500US from Al Majmoua in order to purchase more merchandise for his shop. This is his fifth loan and he has always paid on schedule.

The loans have influenced his life in a good way. Mohamed is known for his work because he sells quality products. His customers are his friends and neighbors. When he first started his business, Mohamed faced some difficulty paying the rent of his shop. He used to have a pick up that he used to sell his products. He plans to expand his business.

loans.use: To purchase more merchandise for resale.

loans.name: Vin

texts.en:
Mrs. Vin N. was born in 1978 and she now lives in Beong Veng village in Kampong Cham province. She has 3 hectares where she cultivates rice to earn a living. In this plantation, she faces an obstacle because her field is infertile. To deal with this problem, Mrs. Vin N. decided to ask for a loan to buy fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive. Her husband, Mr. Nai Nat, is a pig breeder.

Mrs. Vin N. is 30 years old and the mother of two children, one of whom is attending the local school while the other is too young to work or study because that child is only five years old. Her husband is also in the photo.

loans.use: to buy fertilizer to support the field to make her crop more productive

loans.name: Anonymous
loans.use: Working Capital

loans.name: Lizbeth  Vanessa

texts.es:
Compró productos que le faltaban en su tienda.
Lizbeth recién comenzó su negocio hace un año cuando tuvo su bebé, a raíz de que quiso independizarse. Empezó con un pequeño capital que le dio su esposo, y poco a poco con sus ganancias, y desde hace unos meses con los préstamos de EDAPROSPO, fue agrandando su negocio de ropa, sábanas y otros productos. Como su esposo se encarga de cubrir los gastos del hogar, ella puede invertir todas sus ganancias en la tienda que comparte con su mamá.
A sus diecinueve años Lizbeth tiene toda su vida delante, y por el momento sus planes por el futuro son de expandir a su negocio, y poco a poco desarrollar un buen hogar para su futura familia.
texts.en:
She purchased products that were missing from her store. Lizbeth only recently started her business, about one year ago, when she had her baby, which led her to want to be independent. She started with a small amount of capital give to her by her husband and, little by little with her earnings and loans from EDAPROSPO, she grew her business selling clothing, sheets, and other products. Since her husband is in charge of covering the household expenses, she can invest all her earnings into the store that she shares with her mother. At 19 years of age, Lizbeth has her whole life ahead of her. For now, her plans for the future include expanding her business developing a good home for her family.

Translated from Spanish by Mary Lynn Malaby, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of products that were missing from her store.

loans.name: Kristina

texts.en:
Kristina has owned a small food store in the Ilala neighborhood of Dodoma. She belongs to Wazo "A" group loan (group code 2011).  She currently earns an average monthly profit of $25. Every day she works at her business for 6 hours.

She is requesting her first loan from BRAC Tanzania so that she can buy more food items for her business. She hopes that through this loan, her profits will increase and she will be able to grow her business, so she can pay school fees for her child and get more food for her family.  

Kristina is 40 years old, married, and has one 19-year-old child.

loans.use: To buy more food items for her business

loans.name: Ana

texts.es: Ana tiene 38 años, es una dulce madre de dos pequeños hijos, quienes son su mayor tesoro; y junto a su pareja tratan de brindarles las mejores condiciones de vida, por ello compraron la casa  que les costó mucho construir. Desde muy joven tuvo que trabajar para ayudar a su familia, y dentro de sus actividades económicas que realizó encontró su verdadera vocación en los bordados, empezó a realizar diversos tejidos, ya que su creatividad la hicieron reconocida dentro de las diversas fábricas en las que trabajó. Más ahora adquirió una máquina especial para tejidos y bordados, la cual la ayuda a seguir trabajando, pero en su domicilio, pues le llevan grandes cantidades de prendas para que realice los tejidos o diversos adornos que sólo Ana, con su gran creatividad, puede realizar. Desde entonces se siente más tranquila, ya que dejó de lado las horas de ausencia de su hogar y tiene la posibilidad de trabajar y cuidar a su familia. Ahora tiene el anhelo de mejorar sus servicios con maquinaria más especializada o con instrumentos que le faciliten el arduo trabajo, pues algunos días tiene que terminar de bordar o tejer desde 100 a 300 prendas. Ana tiene una gran simpatía con su equipo de trabajo, pues dentro del grupo viene trabajando más de 5 años en MFP, le grada sentirse útil para realizar algunas tareas administrativas, las que le han ido ayudando en el trascurso de su permanencia. Más ahora este es su primer préstamo individual, fuera de su grupo, pues requiere mayor capital de trabajo. Con la finalidad de adquirir algunas herramientas o telares para sus trabajos, Ana optó por solicitar un préstamo de 3000 soles que serán invertidos en la compra de sus materiales de trabajo.
texts.en:
Ana, 38, is a doting mother of two small children, her treasures, and she and her husband try to give them the best. For that, they bought a house that cost a lot of build. From the time she was a girl, she's had to work hard to help her family and, among the jobs that she's done to earn money, she found that her true vocation is embroidery. She started by making different fabrics because her creativity had led her to be recognized for that skill at the factories where she worked. Later, she acquired a special machine for knitting and embroidery which allowed her to continue working--at home now--on clothing brought to her because only she, with her great creativity, could provide the level of decoration required. Since then, she's been happier because she no longer has to be away from home. She now has the chance to both work and care for her family. Next she wants to improve the level of services that she provides with a more specialized machine and instruments that will ease her difficult work, work that on some days requires her to complete 100 to 300 clothing pieces. Ana likes her working group, a group that's been working with MFP for more than 5 years, and she's grateful for the help they've provided with certain administrative tasks, something that's been very valuable during her time there. This will be her first individual loan, outside of the group, because she needs a larger amount of working capital. With the goal of buying some tools or cloth, Ana is applying for a 3000-soles loan that she will use to buy supplies for her business.

Translated from Spanish by Jere Wiseman, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Buy supplies for embroidery business.

loans.name: Regzenlham

texts.en:
Regzenlham D. lives with her husband and two children in Ulaanbaatar, the capital city of Mongolia. Her two children are high school students. Regzenlham has a small retail business selling women’s fashion accessories such as earrings and necklaces.

In 2000, she rented a stall in the Narantuul market, the largest open market in Ulaanbaatar. Since then her business has expanded and her working capital has increased from 2,500,000 MNT (1 USD=1,500 MNT) to 4,500,000 MNT. Her husband is also involved in her small business. When she travels to Ereen, China (a border town where cheap goods enter Mongolia) to purchase elegant women’s fashion accessories, her husband runs her stall.

Regzenlham and her husband hope to send their two children to universities of their choice. She requests a loan to purchase more fashion accessories from Ereen to increase her business inventory.

loans.use: to purchase more fashion accessories for re-sale

loans.name: Luong Thi

texts.en:
T. Luong Thi (919010602) lives in the town of Vinh Phuc and is a married mother of 5 school-aged children. To making a living, T. operates a family member's business venture in the agriculture sector raising crops. While not the only means for generating revenue, the main source of income for the business comes primarily from planting and harvesting fruits and vegetables for sale. T. has been engaged in this business for over 5 years and earns approximately 2,500,000 VND a month from these activities.

In 2001, T. joined TYM Fund to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. T. has successfully repaid her previous loan from TYM Fund that was used to purchase additional seeds, seedlings and young crops for raising. T. requests a new loan of 10,000,000 VND to pay for services to increase crop yield. The loan will be T.’s 9th loan from TYM Fund. T. plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to supplement her family's income.

loans.use: To pay for services to increase crop yield

loans.name: Joyce's Group

texts.en: K. Joyce, 56, is a hard working and devoted married mother of 12 children. Those children who are still in school are at the University and in Secondary school. Joyce also helps to care for three dependants. She is a business lady selling bananas and clothes. Being that she sells from Akashayi in Ibaare trading centre, she is able to manage both businesses. This is Joyce’s sixth loan and her loans have always helped her in buying more fertilizers and manure for her banana plantation plus buying more clothes; and as a result, she has been able to increase her monthly profits to 150,000 shillings because of her quality matooke and clothes for sale. She has a dream of having a happy and united family as well as having business expansion and profit increase. Joyce needs a loan to help with improving her banana plantation by employing manpower and buying fertilizers.

loans.use: Manpower, fertilizer and clothes for resale.

loans.name: Ejike

texts.en:
Ejike E. is currently in the business of selling rice, beans, meat, etc. at the resturant. She is requesting a loan to buy more chairs and tables for enough accommodation.  Ejike is 30 years old and is married. Her husband is a business man. She has 5 children and her children go to school.  With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: To buy more chairs and tables for restaurant.

loans.name: Karla Ivon

texts.es: Karla Ivon L. López  tiene la edad de 28 años. Actualmente es una mujer casada. Tiene 1 hijo a su cargo. La actividad económica es la venta de ropa usada. La ubicación de su negocio es en su vivienda. Hace más de 3 años que se dedica  a este negocio. Karla inicio colocando sus productos en su vivienda al experimentar que ciertos, clientes llegaban a su casa a ver sus productos, pero por consejos de una amiga decide realizar las ventas de su ropa de manera ambulante, a ciertas personas que son amigas suyas, además algunas veces su hermana sale con ella a vender la ropa. El financiamiento que esta solicitando es para capital de trabajo par la compra de camisetas, vestidos y  pantalones. Su deseo es mejorar los ingresos de la actividad para asegurarle a su hijos el futuro de sus estudios.
texts.en:
Karla Ivon L. L. is 28 years old. She is a married woman and she has a son in her care. She owns a used clothing business, which she runs from her own home. She has been running the business for more than three years. Karla started displaying some of her products in her home because some clients used to come to her home to view the items. But following some advice from a friend she started selling her clothing door to door. Sometimes she sells alongside her friends and her sister. The loan she is requesting will be used as working capital, to purchase t-shirts, dresses and slacks. Her wish is to improve her business income so that she can secure her children with a future and be able to send them to school.


Translated from Spanish by Erika Lindig, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Working Capital.

loans.name: Luis

texts.es:
Luis es socio del Bancomunal Los Sureños, es casado tiene 44 años, tres hijos de 18, 17 y 11 años que están estudiando en la escuela estatal.
Luis es Cuzqueño, desde que llego a Lima  empezó trabajar en un taller de mecánica como ayudante por mas de 10 años, hasta que se independizó, con los ahorros alquilo un local y puso su taller de mecánica, cuenta con una persona que lo ayuda.    
Desde que esta en Finca aprendió como trabajar con los prestamos que recibe.
Luís necesita un préstamo de 800 soles, para compra de repuestos, de pernos, soldaduras para su taller de mecánica. 
El sueño de Luís es comprar un carro, para darlo en alquiler, y poder techar su casa.
texts.en:
Luis is a member of the “Los Sureños” (The Southerners) Community Bank. He is 44 years old, married, and has three children. His children are 18, 17, and 11 years old and are studying in public school.

Luis is from Cuzco. Since he arrived in Lima, he began to work as an assistant in a mechanic shop for more than 10 years. Since he became independent, he has rented a place with his savings and has set up a mechanic shop, where he has a helper.

Since becoming part of Finca, he has learned how to work with the loans that he receives.

Luis needs a loan of 800 PEN for the purchase of spare parts, bolts, and welding parts for his mechanic shop.

Luis’ dream is to buy a car so that he can rent it, and to be able to roof his house.

Translated from Spanish by Kathleen O'Connell, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of spare parts, bolts, and welding parts for his mechanic shop.

loans.name: Ma. Linda

texts.en:
Ma. Linda D. is a 41-year-old rice grower and mother of two. She is also a chicken, pig and duck farmer. She has been in these various businesses to help her husband earn income to pay for the food, clothing, electricity, tuition and daily costs of their family.

She would like to ask for a loan of 5,000 Philippine pesos. She will use the loan to purchase 3 sacks of rice seeds, urea, and insecticides.

She is very pleased with the CEVI credit services. She doesn't just receive loans with very low interest, but training and insurance as well.

loans.use: To purchase seed, fertilizer, and insecticide

loans.name: Dora

texts.en:
Dora O. P. is 48 years old and is married with three children.  Dora has a business locale where she sells grocery items and ice cream.  She also has a telephone service (several phones in small cabins where people can pay to make calls).  Her husband is an environmental engineer, specializing in forestry.  He also supports Dora in her business ventures.  

Dora has been working with Kiva partner Manuela Ramos for six years and is a member of the communal bank “San Fernando II.”  She plans to use this loan of 2500 soles to buy more products for her grocery shop.

Because her grocery business has done well, Dora was recently able to add the telephone service.  Dora’s goal is to expand this service.  In this way she hopes to earn more income, particularly because she now has daughters who are beginning their university studies.

loans.use: Products for a grocery store.

loans.name: God Loves Us Group

texts.en:
God Loves Us is a group of five borrowers, led by Fayieh L., living and working in Westpoint, a very poor neighborhood near downtown Monrovia, Liberia.

Fayieh is 44 years old and married with four children aged 8 to 22. He also cares for his siblings and parents. He is a high school graduate.

Fayieh’s business is his pharmacy, buying medicines wholesale and selling to the residents of Westpoint in a small shop. He has been running his business for six years. His dream is to grow his business until he can build a larger permanent shop.

Fayieh is taking the loan to buy additional pharmaceutical drugs wholesale to serve his customers in Westpoint. With the profits from his business he dreams of sending his children to school and moving to a less dangerous neighborhood.

loans.use: To purchase medicines wholesale

loans.name: Jusphine

texts.en:
Jusphine J. is currently in the business of selling bread and is requesting a loan to purchase baking flour.  Jusphine is 39 years old and is Married with a husband that is a driver. She has 4 children and her children go to school.  

With the extra profits from her loan, she hopes to be able to pay school fees for her children.

 BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education , and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions.  In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: purchase baking flour

loans.name: El Amor 1 And 4 Group

texts.en:
Valentina is the group coordinator of El Amor (The Love).  Her story is representative of the others in her group and of Esperanza's Haitian and Dominican clients. Valentina's group is based in Hato Mayor, a rural area in the Dominican Republic that has unreliable access to resources such as potable running water and electricity. Valentina lives with her two children (ages 20 and 19) and one grandson. 

Valentina has proven she is an excellent Esperanza client by repaying seven loans. She plans to use this loan, her eighth, to continue to grow her business and buy more shoes to sell.  She hopes to someday have her own store where she can sell her shoes.  Currently, she sells the shoes from her home.  

Valentina would like to use the money she earns in her business to continue to improve the living conditions in her house. The loans she has taken with Esperanza in the past have helped her to provide for her family.

loans.use: Shoes

loans.name: Juan

texts.en:
Juan O. makes a living running a small store, and is applying for this loan to buy items such as tooth brushes, toothpaste and soap to sell to her customers. She is 29 years old and married. Her husband makes a living as a clerk. They have five children, all of whom are in school. With the extra profits made possible by this loan, she hopes to be able to expand her shop.

BRAC's holistic approach to poverty alleviation and empowerment of the poor encompasses a range of core programs in economic and social development, health, education, and human rights and legal services which are delivered through an extensive network of village organizations. BRAC has become one of the world's largest NGOs as a measured by the scale and diversity of its interventions. In 2007, BRAC started operations in Southern Sudan. The microfinance program, which is targeted towards returning war refugees, has already formed 418 village organizations with more than 14,000 women members.

loans.use: to buy tooth brushes, toothpaste, soap and other items to sell to her customers

loans.name: Eunice

texts.en:
Eunice is a thirty-nine-year-old married mother of four children who are all in school. She lives with her husband and children in a rented apartment in a town called Kade, a commercial town. However, the majority of the inhabitants practice farming as a hobby or as a major occupation alongside other trading activities.

Eunice is a food vendor. She prepares a local dish called kenkey (fermented corn and cassava dough, wrapped in corn or banana leaves). It is served hot with pepper and fried fish. She sells in the morning by the roadside in her community. Eunice buys her ingredients from nearby communities.

She has been in business for four years and wants a loan to procure bags of maize and other ingredients in bulk to expand her business.

loans.use: To purchase maize and other ingredients.

loans.name: Nena

texts.en:
Nena B. is from the town of Northern Poblacion, Calamba, Misamis Occidental. She is 33 years old. Nena is married and has two school-aged children. To make a living, Nena owns & operates a business selling specialty foods like banana cue and fruit salad in the local community. Nena has been engaged in her business for over four years and earns approximately 2,750 PHP a month for these activities.

In 2009, Nena joined GDMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and ability to engage in business activities. Nena is requesting a new loan of 5,000 PHP, which will be used to purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale. This loan will be the first loan taken out by Nena from GDMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve/expand her business. 

About GDMPC:

GDMPC is one of the most progressive cooperatives in Mindanao, Philippines. It has four branches and three unit offices covering the provinces of Zamboanga del Sur, Lanao del Norte and Misamis Occidental. Its membership is composed mostly of farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs.

*Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva.  Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase raw ingredients needed to make products for sale

loans.name: Zamina

texts.en:
Zamina K. is a happy mother of two children. She is 37 years old and married. 

Zamina is a trader. She has been running her own grocery business to help her husband financially. For more that 15 years, she has been selling food, such as sweets, preserved foods, juices, soft drinks, tea, coffee, and many others in her grocery store.

Zamina wishes is to expand her business and offer different types of foods to customers who pass through this market. She works with one aim in mind:  to provide the best possible example and way of life for her beloved children who are all the apple of her eye and the reason for her daily efforts. 

With this opportunity, and with the immense love Zamina feels as a mother, and her desire to succeed, she is appealing to your generosity and is requesting a loan of 1600 AZN to increase the range of her goods.

loans.use: To buy more food to sell

loans.name: Faaga

texts.en:
Faaga T. is 36 and married with 4 children (ages 16 - 24).  She works in her business, planting & harvesting taro for sale.  Faaga has many years of experience in this business.  Faaga needs a loan of WST $2750 to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome.  She plans to use the earnings from her business (estimated to be 500 tala or US $208 per week) to financially support immediate members of her family.

In 2006, Faaga joined SPBD.    This is her 4th loan with SPBD.   SPBD's loans are Faaga's only access to capital because she was never able to qualify for a loan with traditional banks.

The following social metrics for Faaga T. are provided by SPBD*:
Overall Social Metric Score:                1.6 out of 3
Level of Education:                              1.5 out of 3
Level of total Household Income:         2 out of 3
Quality of Household Assets:              1.5 out of 3

*SPBD measures the living conditions of each of its borrowers to track her loan progress. The overall social metric score, provided by SPBD, is based upon a number of factors, such as the condition of the house/household assets, health, education, income level, and family reputation. A higher number represents a higher score. For example, a ""3 out of 3"" on education would mean that the borrower has graduated from university; a ""2 out of 3"" = secondary/high-school, and a ""1 out of 3"" would mean that the borrower is uneducated.

For more information on this score, please see SPBD's partner page at: http://partners.kiva.org/about/aboutPartner?id=15

About SPBD
In 2000, Greg Casagrande founded SPBD and since then, it has expanded from the main island of Upolu in Samoa to Savaii, as well as Tonga. SPBD's philosophy of lending is based upon the Grameen Bank lending method.

Please join SPBD's lending team on KIVA to receive on-the-spot updates on SPBD: http://www.kiva.org/community/viewTeam?team_id=8375

loans.use: to purchase weed-killers such as Gramoxome

loans.name: Namengo Group, Lugazi

texts.en:
Cosmas S. is the leader of his lending group in Lugazi. He is a married man and a carpenter in Kinyoro. He has operated his business for five years. He has two school-going children and he takes care of his siblings and parents. 

His biggest business challenge is having customers that delay payments after services have been rendered. However, he is grateful for the loans that increase his business capital, hence enabling him to carry on even in times of hardship. 

Cosmas makes chairs and desks and would like to introduce the making of very nice sofas in addition to the ones he currently makes. He needs a loan to be able to buy more timber and nails plus other necessities to make his job much easier.

loans.use: Buying more timber and nails plus other necessities to make his job much easier

loans.name: Syprose

texts.en: Syprose A. O. is 43 years old, married and has three children between the ages of 12 and 5. Her business is located at Jua kali in Kisumu. It is situated in a busy market where she is able to catch a large market to purchase her goods. She sells foodsuffs, e.g doughnuts, soft drinks, water and cooking fat. She has been selling to the local people for six years now and she says that the major challenge is the many people in that area who are involved in the same business as hers. So her customers are spoiled by the choice. She is using her loan to add stock to grow her business. She wants the food stall to grow and then she will make it a hotel some day. She hopes to make enough money to give her children a quality education some day. She is a very hardworking and patient lady.

loans.use: To buy more foodstuff

loans.name: Ndoumbé

texts.fr: Ndoumbé N. est une femme de 36 ans, elle est mariée et mère de 2 enfants plus trois autres qu'on lui a confiés. Elle est membre du Banc Villageois de WANGO depuis 12 ans et demi et a eu 25 fois de suite bénéficié de prêts. Elle fait un petit commerce, elle vend sur étalage des produits halieutiques, de l'huile de palme, de la pâte d'arachide etc. Ses bénéfices lui permettent d'assurer la prise en charge de la scolarité des enfants et d'améliorer le bienêtre familiale.
texts.en:
Ndoumbé N. is a 36-year-old married mother of two children in addition to three others under her care. She has been a member of the Wango Village Bank for 12 ½ years and has received 25 loans through them. She has a small business in which she sells fishing products, palm oil, peanut butter, etc. Her income allows her to pay for her children’s education and improve her family’s well-being.

Translated from French by Manuel Carreiro, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: To maintain and promote her business

loans.name: Mercedes' Group

texts.en: Mercedes D. C. is from Barangay Paniki, Bagabag, Nueva Vizcaya. She is 46 years old and is the group leader of a ten-member group loan offered by ASKI. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults. Mercedes is widowed and has four adult children. She owns and operates a general store, selling a variety of different products in the local community. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month. In 2006, Mercedes joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI. This previous loan was used to purchase additional products to sell. Mercedes is requesting a new loan of 8,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offering. This loan will be her ninth from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has twenty-one branches covering the Central and Northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly of farmers, fisherfolk and small entrepreneurs. *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand her product offering

loans.name: Nouhad

texts.en: Nouhad is 42 and married with three children. With the heavy expenses of raising a family she decided, in 2000, to help her husband by running a small business as a home-based beauty-products vendor in addition to offering beauty services to her clients. Nouhad is requesting a loan of $1,200 to buy more cosmetics and hair products to increase her sales and her income. Nouhad is like the majority of the woman in Lebanon who try to help their families as best they can by having a business in their homes.

loans.use: buy more cosmetic products

loans.name: Tasiana's Group

texts.en:
Tasiana E. is from the village of Locuban, Dumalinao, Zamboanga del Sur. She is 57 years old and is the group leader of this five-member group loan offered by PMPC. While each member of the group receives an individual loan, they are all collectively responsible for paying back the loans of their fellow group members if someone is delinquent or defaults.

Tasiana is married and has six adult children.She owns and operates a business providing delivery service to local community members. She has been engaged in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 8,000 PHP a month.

In 2009, Tasiana joined PMPC to gain access to financial services to help improve her living situation and her ability to engage in business activities. She has successfully repaid a previous loan of 9,000 PHP from PMPC.

Tasiana is requesting a new loan of 9,000 PHP which will be used to fully paid her motorcycle service. This loan will be her 3rd from PMPC. She plans to use the additional revenue generated from the business to improve the general living conditions of her family. 


About PMPC:
Paglaum Multi-Purpose Cooperative (PMPC) is one of the most progressive cooperatives in northwestern Mindanao. It reaches out to the rural poor using the Grameen model.


 *Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: fully paid of her motorcycle services

loans.name: Virginia

texts.en:
Virginia is 26 years old and married with one child who goes to school.  She runs a boutique where she sells clothes and shoes to earn a living.  Her husband is employed and therefore earns a salary.  She saves part of her income with her group in Faulu Kenya called Ebenezer Njenga.  Since she joined Faulu Kenya she has learned to keep business records from the training they offered her group, and her business has grown. 

She has requested a loan of 50,000 KES from Faulu Kenya to add to her stock of shoes. She hopes to increase her business into wholesale sales and to improve her living standards in the future.  She describes herself as hardworking, focused and determined.

loans.use: To add to her stock of shoes for sale.

loans.name: Adela

texts.en: Adela F. owns and operates a general store selling both food and daily use products in her local community. She is 59 years old, married and has four grown-up children. She is from the village of Brgy. Poblacion, Diadi, Nueva Vizcaya. Adela has been in her business for over ten years and earns approximately 4,000 Philippine pesos (PHP) a month. In 2009, Adela joined ASKI to gain access to financial services to help improve her living conditions and enable her to engage in business activities. Adela has successfully repaid a previous loan of 5,000 PHP from ASKI which was used to purchase products to sell. Adela is requesting a new loan of 7,000 PHP which will be used to purchase new items to expand her product offerings. This will be her second loan from ASKI. She plans to use the additional revenue to improve the general living conditions of her family. About ASKI: ASKI is one of the most successful microfinance institutions in the Philippines. It has 29 branches covering the central and northeastern areas. Its clients are mostly farmers, fisherfolks and small entrepreneurs. Note: To maximize efficiency and reduce costs, this loan was posted using a template to automate the translation by Kiva. Given that manual translation of entrepreneur profiles is costly, Kiva created this template for our Field Partner to allow them to continue to post loans in English while providing quality and accurate information to Kiva lenders.

loans.use: To purchase new items to expand product offering

loans.name: Nou

texts.en: Mrs. Nou Ri/tina, 29, is the mother of three school-aged kids, who are all under her care. She has been married for many years to Mat Lim, 31, who is a taxi driver earning a suitable income for their family. To make a living, Nou Ri/tina weaves and sells cradles made from small pieces of clothing. She saves up many sets of cradles before selling them to retail vendors in the local market for a profit. She currently faces an obstacle: she has an old house which often needs repairs. This bad situation is burdening the family with uncomfortable living conditions. To help solve the problem, Nou Ri/tina is applying for a loan to repair the house.

loans.use: To make repairs to her house

loans.name: Manuel

texts.es:
Manuel de 52 años, vive en la Primavera de Duran (perímetro urbano fue originalmente irregular, con varios cerros, riachuelos y lagunas que aún se presentan como restos de una ecología en disolución). El tiene un pequeño puesto de verduras en Duran. 

Antes de tener el puesto de verdura el vivía en la Sierra del Ecuador pero por la falta de oportunidades decidió ir a Duran con sus cuatro hijos y su esposa. El puesto de verduras le ha servido para mantener a su familia durante todo este tiempo trabaja todos los días hasta el anochecer. 

Pero para tener mas verduras y clientes quiere comprar con el préstamo legumbres y verduras para su negocio. En el futuro quiere tener su propio negocio.
texts.en:
